wikipedia_page.main: John Rogers (1807–1867) was an English barrister, known as a naturalist particularly interested in orchids, and gardener.

Originally built on the site of a Tudor farmstead in 1714, Riverhill House and estate were purchased in 1840 by John Rogers. A keen botanist and a contemporary of Charles Darwin, Rogers purchased the property because of its sheltered location and lime-free soil. Rogers was an early member of the Royal Horticultural Society and a patron of Victorian plant-hunters.

The Riverhill estate include gardens first established by John Rogers in 1842. The huge Turkey oak at the front of the house was brought back as an acorn by a previous owner returning from the Crimean War.Country House Rescue - Riverhill House  The garden also has cedar trees planted in the 1840s.
